review.title: GeomRDF: A Geodata Converter with a Fine-Grained Structured Representation of Geometry in the Web
review.abstract: In recent years, with the advent of the web of data, a growing number of national mapping agencies tend to publish their geospatial data as Linked Data. However, differences between traditional GIS data models and Linked Data model can make the publication process more complicated. Besides, it may require, to be done, the setting of several parameters and some expertise in the semantic web technologies. In addition, the use of standards like GeoSPARQL (or ad hoc predicates) is mandatory to perform spatial queries on published geospatial data. In this paper, we present GeomRDF, a tool that helps users to convert spatial data from traditional GIS formats to RDF model easily. It generates geometries represented as GeoSPARQL WKT literal but also as structured geometries that can be exploited by using only the RDF query language, SPARQL. GeomRDF was implemented as a module in the RDF publication platform Datalift. A validation of GeomRDF has been realized against the French administrative units dataset (provided by IGN France).

sections.heading: 3 GeomRDF Components
sections.text: In this section, we describe the various components of GeomRDF (see Figure 1) and the process that transforms a spatial dataset from traditional GIS formats into RDF. GeomRDF comprises three components: the input parser, the feature parser and the RDF builder. In the following sections, we outline these components.

sections.heading: 3.1 The Input Parser:
sections.text: GeomRDF takes as input ESRI shapefile [8], Geospatial DBMS or GML [20]. sections.heading: 3.2 Feature Parser:
sections.text: This component iterates on the characteristics that are extracted in the first step and classifies their properties according to their type, either thematic or geometrical. For one characteristic, the parser tests all the properties and stores for each property information such as their name, their value and their type. To show how the characteristics are processed, we take as an example the "Paris" section, which is defined in the administrative units produced by IGN France. sections.heading: 3.4 External Libraries
sections.text: The actual version of GeomRDF (a platform-independent version implemented in Java) only depends on two essential libraries: GeoTools [15] and OpenRDF Sesame [14]. Their descriptions are listed below: GeoTools is an open source Java library that provides methods for manipulating geospatial data. It includes many features such as support for a wide range of formats (including ESRI shapefile, XML (GML, KML), and geospatial databases), and a coordinate transformation service that provides descriptions and operations of coordinate systems such as map projections and data transformations. Data structures used in GeoTools are based on the standards of the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC). OpenRDF Sesame is an open source Java framework for processing RDF data. Its features include SesDF parsers, storage solutions (triplestore queries), and query queries supported by the XARG main library.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We presented the input format that supports GeomRDF, its network components and its dependencies on external libraries. We detailed how the geometric information is structured according to an ontology that reuses and expands the existing geographical vocabularies, and showed an example of this structuring in the case of multi-polygon geometry. The GeomRDF tool was implemented as a module in the Datalift platform. We illustrated an application of this tool by detailing the process of publishing the French administrative dataset provided by IGN France. So far, GeomRDF only accepts geospatial formats as input data. However, it would be useful to accept text file formats such as CSV that contain direct location information, and to convert these textual coordinates in instances of the Geom class: then such a linking of information via any way could be used to visualize information.

referenceMentions.context: Over the last decade, efforts to share geospatial data on the Web have mainly focused on the development and the standardization by ISO TC 211 and the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) of domain-specific good practices and tools called Spatial Data Infrastructures (SDIs) [5].
These good practices have been particularly confirmed by the adoption by the European Parliament of the INSPIRE Directive establishing an infrastructure for spatial information in the Community [22].
At the same time, generic good practices for data sharing on the Web called Linked Data have been developed and supported by the W3C [3].
To be overcome, it requires not only geolocation vocabularies, but also specific tools that automatise the conversion of existing geospatial data into Linked Data [31].

Many knowledge extraction and data conversion tools have been proposed to generate RDF data from unstructured or structured data sources [26] [4] [6] [1] [29] [24] [17], but just a few vocabularies and their associated conversion tools have been implemented to address the issue of converting easily geospatial data into the RDF model.

TripleGeo [23] is an extension of Geometry2RDF that takes into account, in the transformation process, the GeoSPARQL vocabulary.
shp2GeoSPARQL [27] is also an extension of Geometry2RDF which transforms geometrical information from geospatial datasets to RDF.
However, there are very few triplestores that implement this standard yet [2], so that GeoSPARQL spatial operators and functions can not be used commonly with the available linked geospatial data.
A data interlinking module based on the Silk Framework [28] is also available within the Datalift platform when more complicated interlinking processes are needed.
